title: How to Make a Salmon Mousse

steps.headline: Assemble all your ingredients and kitchen utensils.
Let the gelatine soak in a bowl of cold water for a minimum of ten minutes.
Chop the smoked salmon and dill into tiny pieces using a sharp knife and chopping board.
steps.description: If you're using smoked salmon flakes, make sure they're small enough. You shouldn't find lumps in the mousse; it should have a light and airy consistency.

steps.headline: Whip the full fat cream in a bowl until it's sufficiently thick.
steps.description: You can test this by seeing what happens if you take a spoonful out of the bowl. If the cream settles back in, you need to whip it some more.

steps.headline: Heat the lemon juice in a pan on the stove until it simmers.
steps.description: Then remove the pan from the heat.

steps.headline: Remove the gelatin leaves from the cold water and mix them in with the heated lemon juice.
Add the other ingredients and stir them in lightly.
Rinse a glass or ceramic bowl or mold.
Pour the mixture into the bowl and cover it with cling wrap.
Place the bowl in the fridge and let it sit for at least 12 hours without being disturbed.
steps.description: If you move it, the shape of the mousse might be affected, which could lead to a less visually pleasing dish.

steps.headline: Remove the salmon mousse from the fridge to garnish it and prepare for serving.
steps.description: If you've used a mold, place a serving plate upside-down on top of the mold, then turn the mold over carefully. This way, the salmon mousse should settle onto the serving plate without losing its shape.

steps.headline: Decorate the mousse with prawns, fresh dill, or any other decoration of your choice.
Serve the mousse with rye bread or boiled potatoes.

text: Assemble all your ingredients and kitchen utensils.  Let the gelatine soak in a bowl of cold water for a minimum of ten minutes.  Chop the smoked salmon and dill into tiny pieces using a sharp knife and chopping board. If you're using smoked salmon flakes, make sure they're small enough. You shouldn't find lumps in the mousse; it should have a light and airy consistency. Whip the full fat cream in a bowl until it's sufficiently thick. You can test this by seeing what happens if you take a spoonful out of the bowl. If the cream settles back in, you need to whip it some more. Heat the lemon juice in a pan on the stove until it simmers. Then remove the pan from the heat. Remove the gelatin leaves from the cold water and mix them in with the heated lemon juice.  Add the other ingredients and stir them in lightly.  Rinse a glass or ceramic bowl or mold.  Pour the mixture into the bowl and cover it with cling wrap.  Place the bowl in the fridge and let it sit for at least 12 hours without being disturbed. If you move it, the shape of the mousse might be affected, which could lead to a less visually pleasing dish. Remove the salmon mousse from the fridge to garnish it and prepare for serving. If you've used a mold, place a serving plate upside-down on top of the mold, then turn the mold over carefully. This way, the salmon mousse should settle onto the serving plate without losing its shape. Decorate the mousse with prawns, fresh dill, or any other decoration of your choice.  Serve the mousse with rye bread or boiled potatoes.
